prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RA=16, Dec=26 (6 galaxies): measure Lsubmm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal includes 5 sources from the Q1623 field (redshift 2 to 2.2), plus one highz ULIRG at z~0.8. None of the sources are known to be lensed.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All Science Goals in this proposal are the same except for the sources in each. Sources have been grouped into the science goals only by distribution on the sky. We require to measure continuum fluxes close to rest-frame 850micron in sources with redshift 0.6 to 3.0 (dominated by redshifts 1.5 to 2.3). The science goals can be achieved with any resolution between about 2.0 and 2.5arcsec. All sources are more compact than the ~15" largest angular scale achievable with our chosen array configuration (resolution=2").
All sources have measured CO luminosities (single dish or interferometric). Expected continuum fluxes at 850micron (or at about 500micron for the z>2 sources) are listed for each source. These have been estimated from the CO luminosity and the scaling relation between 850micron luminosity and CO luminosity seen in nearby galaxies (see the scientific justification text).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RA=23, Dec=12 (6 galaxies): measure Lsubmm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal includes 6 galaxies from the Q2343 field. None of them are known to be lensed. Redshift range is 2 to 2.2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All Science Goals in this proposal are the same except for the sources in each. Sources have been grouped into the science goals only by distribution on the sky. We require to measure continuum fluxes close to rest-frame 850micron in sources with redshift 0.6 to 3.0 (dominated by redshifts 1.5 to 2.3). The science goals can be achieved with any resolution between about 2.0 and 2.5arcsec. All sources are more compact than the ~15" largest angular scale achievable with our chosen array configuration (resolution=2").
All sources have measured CO luminosities (single dish or interferometric). Expected continuum fluxes at 850micron (or at about 500micron for the z>2 sources) are listed for each source. These have been estimated from the CO luminosity and the scaling relation between 850micron luminosity and CO luminosity seen in nearby galaxies (see the scientific justification text).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RA=02, Dec=0 (8 galaxies): measure Lsubmm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal includes 4 galaxies at z~2.4, 2 galaxies at z~1.2, and 2 galaxies at z~0.7. Only two are known to be lensed (magnifications 25 and 2.5).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All Science Goals in this proposal are the same except for the sources in each. Sources have been grouped into the science goals only by distribution on the sky. We require to measure continuum fluxes close to rest-frame 850micron in sources with redshift 0.6 to 3.0 (dominated by redshifts 1.5 to 2.3). These have been estimated from the CO luminosity and the scaling relation between 850micron luminosity and CO luminosity seen in nearby galaxies (see the scientific justification text).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RA=09, Dec=0 (7 galaxies): measure Lsubmm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal includes 7 galaxies, of which only three are known to be lensed (magnifications of 2, 5 and 6). Two galaxies have redshifts ~0.7; the other galaxies have redshifts in the range 2.4 to 2.6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All Science Goals in this proposal are the same except for the sources in each. Sources have been grouped into the science goals only by distribution on the sky. These have been estimated from the CO luminosity and the scaling relation between 850micron luminosity and CO luminosity seen in nearby galaxies (see the scientific justification text).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RA=09, Dec=0 (8 galaxies): measure Lsubmm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal includes 8 galaxies, none of which are known to be lensed. Six of the galaxies are at redshift ~1.5, and the remaining two are at redshift 1.8 and 2.2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All Science Goals in this proposal are the same except for the sources in each. Sources have been grouped into the science goals only by distribution on the sky. We require to measure continuum fluxes close to rest-frame 850micron in sources with redshift 0.6 to 3.0 (dominated by redshifts 1.5 to 2.3). The science goals can be achieved with any resolution between about 2.0 and 2.5arcsec. All sources are more compact than the ~15" largest angular scale achievable with our chosen array configuration (resolution=2").
All sources have measured CO luminosities (single dish or interferometric). Expected continuum fluxes at 850micron (or at about 500micron for the z>2 sources) are listed for each source. These have been estimated from the CO luminosity and the scaling relation between 850micron luminosity and CO luminosity seen in nearby galaxies (see the scientific justification text).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We have found that the global 850micron (L850) and CO luminosities (LCO) in a large sample of nearby galaxies are related to better than 0.3dex. However, high-z galaxies (z~0.5-3) with measured restframe 850micron fluxes and CO luminosities are scarce: the few galaxies in the literature appear to follow a relationship similar to that of local galaxies, but the result is not statistically firm, and plagued by lensing and extrapolation uncertainties.
We propose continuum observations (~850micron restframe; Band4) of the dust emission in a sample of galaxies at z=0.6--3 which have a measured CO luminosity. Our goal is to characterize the evolution of the Lsubmm-LCO relationship with redshift. Together with the local scaling, the results will enable molecular mass (Mgas) determinations in thousands of galaxies with measurements of the former (Planck, Herschel, ALMA). Since both ALMA and Herschel can also probe the LFIR of high-z sources, a few continuum observations can thus constrain Mgas (from Lsubmm), Star-formation rate (SFR; from LFIR), and thus SFE, enabling an efficient study of galaxy evolution in thousands of galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
